thread.title: Tennessee wins 38-31; Georgia loses Chubb
thread.title_full: Tennessee wins 38-31; Georgia loses Chubb | savannahnow.com

author: Marc Weiszer
title: Tennessee wins 38-31; Georgia loses Chubb
text:
Photos Back | Next Brant Sanderlin/Atlanta Journal-Constitution via AP
Georgia running back Nick Chubb is helped off the field after injuring his left knee Saturday.
Back | Next Tennessee coach Butch Jones, left, shakes hands with Georgia coach Mark Richt after Tennessee won 38-31 on Saturday.
Back | Next Photos by Wade Payne/The Associated Press
Tennessee quarterback Josh Dobbs (11) tries to avoid being tackled by Georgia defensive lineman John Atkins (97) and cornerback Devin Gillespie (36) during the first half Saturday.

SIGN UP FOR SUBSCRIBER BENEFITS As a Savannah Morning News / savannahnow.com subscriber, you're eligible for members-only discounts. Download your coupons now. By Marc Weiszer KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — A Georgia football team staggered a week earlier was dealt another body blow on the first offensive play of the game Saturday against Tennessee when Nick Chubb went down on the Neyland Stadium turf with a gruesome injury to his left knee that left him screaming in pain.
The star running back’s extended absence would change the complexion of the season for the Bulldogs.
It already was altered after Georgia’s 38-31 loss to a reeling Volunteers team that left the No. 19 Bulldogs in chase mode again in the SEC East race and probably closes the book on any chance to reach the college football playoff.
After the game, coach Mark Richt said of Chubb: “I’m optimistic that it won’t require surgery, but I can’t say 100 percent. I just don’t want to give too much information because I don’t know for sure. As of right now, we’re still pretty hopeful that it won’t require surgery, but we’re not 100 percent sure of that. We’ve got to get some confirmation (Sunday).”
Georgia (4-2, 2-2 SEC) couldn’t win without Chubb, but it went on a wild ride before having its five-game winning streak to Tennessee (3-3, 1-2) snapped. It was the second straight loss after a 28-point home loss to Alabama.
“You have to be positive,” Richt said. “If everybody thinks the sky is falling, and everybody starts pointing fingers and everybody gets real negative, it’s hard to continue to finish the season and continue to strive for the goals that we have. … It’s hard to sleep on a night like tonight, and it’s going to be hard to wake up and know that it really happened.”
What happened was Georgia opened a 24-3 lead and then gave up 28 unanswered points before Greyson Lambert hit Reggie Davis on a 48-yard touchdown pass on the first play of the fourth quarter to tie the game at 31.
“I don’t think everybody just dropped their heads and said, ‘Oh, no the game’s over,’ by any stretch,” Richt said of how the team reacted to Chubb’s injury. “But everybody loves Nick Chubb. Everybody respects Nick Chubb. I’m sure the Bulldog Nation’s heart sank when you see a guy like that on the sideline like that.”
The Bulldogs defense couldn’t get stops. It surrendered 519 yards and was shredded by quarterback Josh Dobbs, who completed 25 of 42 passes for a career-high 312 yards with three touchdowns and an interception and rushed for 118 and two touchdowns on 18 carries.
“We’ve got to finish, that’s the big thing,” defensive coordinator Jeremy Pruitt said. “You’re in position to make a tackle, you’ve got to finish the tackle. You’ve got to wrap up, bring your feet and we’ve got to gang tackle.”
Georgia still had a chance to tie the game but Davis dropped a sure touchdown at the Vols’ 5-yard after he beat defensive back Malik Foreman on the play with 3:52 to go on a third-and-9 from the Georgia 44.
Georgia later drove from its own 1 to the Tennessee 22 with 6 seconds to play before an illegal substitution penalty put it at the 27.
Lambert’s pass to the end zone intended for Malcolm Mitchell in the right corner was broken up by Brian Randolph as time expired.
“There’s really no other option but to regroup and come back and come back fighting,” said Lambert, who was 15 of 32 for 279 yards and two touchdowns. “I feel like we’re a resilient team, and we’ll be able to come back and move forward from this.”
Chubb was lying on the trainer’s table in the third quarter wearing a sweat suit as the Volunteers went ahead 31-24 on a 2-yard touchdown pass from Dobbs to Alvin Kamara.
Georgia went three and out on its first three offensive possessions after losing Chubb with what was announced as a left knee injury.
Replays of the injury made viewers cringe.
Chubb took a pitch and was knocked towards the ground by defensive back Emmanuel Mosely, but put a hand down to steady himself and spun around and was hit near the sideline by linebacker Jalen Reeves-Maybin.
Chubb had his left leg planted, and it gave out after the hit by Reeves-Maybin.
“A lot of us prayed for him and saw how he was doing and went over there and tried to check up on him,” Lambert said.
Chubb was a Heisman Trophy contender who led all active NCAA players with a career rushing average of 127.3 yards per game.
“He’s probably the least deserving person for something like that to happen to,” Lambert said. “It was tough, but we had what, 59 minutes and 30 seconds left in the ballgame. It’s an next-man-up mentality.
Chubb had tied Herschel Walker for a Georgia record last week with his 13th straight 100-yard rushing game.
“Keep your head up @NickChubb21!!!,” Walker tweeted in the first half.
Sony Michel rushed for 145 yards on 22 carries with Chubb sidelined.
Georgia will look to avoid a three-game slide when it plays Missouri on Saturday night in Athens.
“It’s a wild league,” Richt said of where Georgia goes from here. “A lot of teams are capable of beating each other. We’re definitely not losing hope by any means of our goal to get to Atlanta. Our big thing is to get better. Our big thing is to find a way to beat Missouri.”
